commentBody: Fun puzzle! Anyone else absolutely terrible at laser tag? Last time I did it was on a date in college and I got absolutely destroyed by a seven year old birthday party.

Loved this one. Wish I could remember that it‚Äôs NOOB,  not, newb. I get it wrong. Every. Time. ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I‚Äôm old. And never played video games. This was a lot of fun. Happy Tuesday, y‚Äôall! Thanks, Spencer!
Shape for SOLID was my only mis-fill... except for the typo on 27D where I accidentally hit Y instead of U. If team building exercises result in a TRyST, you're probably doing it wrong ...

I've never been on Tinder, but can't you indirectly edit your age by editing your birthdate?  

I'm assuming it can't be edited because it's a calculated field.

It's been decades since I've been to a BASEMENT PARTY, but at the ones I attended the lights were on (if not bright). I get dancing in the dark; just not in the basement.

I've also used infrared film in a conventional camera, but that's *not* a knock on the 19A answer.

Nice SHOT, Spencer.


N.B. I hope the wordplay in the cutline (caption) on today's lead photo doesn't get called an error as was yesterday's.

Very fun puzzle! My lack of cultural (pop or otherwise...) knowledge only brought me trouble in the bottom-right corner; rest was smooth, and I enjoyed the theme. Love the Questlove feature; I've been getting into the Roots a lot lately, so it's cool to see them make an appearance in the crossword.

The "The brother in my brother's keeper?" clue threw me off.  The brother in revealed in the answer was deceased when the conversation referenced in the clue occurred between Cain and God.  In Genesis, the whole conversation included in the clue was focused on the murderous brother, not the victim.  I know crosswords try to be purposely veiled, but this clue just seemed inaccurate.

There are three kinds of solvers. Those who, after reading today‚Äôs revealer, recall the puzzle of 5/16/21 with dazzled admiration, those who recall it with horror, and those who haven‚Äôt done that one yet.
Anyone in the last category, I recommend a visit to the archive.  Once you‚Äôre finished with your BASEMENT PARTY, of course.

A little easy for a Tuesday solve. 4:45 under my average. I usually wait for the middle crosses on N* *b before deciding between Noob or Newb. Jumped the gun and had to go back and fix. Also had raps before rams. Otherwise a nice easy solve
J A Y S  W I N.
Liked this puzzle! Got my fastest Tuesday time ever!

Pretty fun easy puzzle today.  Enjoyed the SHOT IN THE DARK theme.

The one clue that tripped me up was BARBACOA.  I have no idea what that is.  When I saw BARB I was thinking BARBECUE and then SHOT IN THE DARK made it BARBA--- which made it even more confusing.

When I got all the crossing clues making it BARBACOA I was sure I was going to have "Something amiss" but it was right.

NICELY DONE, Mr. Leach! A real TREAT of a puzzle that read a bit like a menu of dinner options (and that's not a complaint.) With all due respect to the talented Questlove who shows up twice in this puzzle, seeing EXTREME took me to this instead: https://youtu.be/UrIiLvg58SY?si=_2BamHpVkdsie-oo [Still wondering if I should have something SOLID or just a BOWL of SOUP...maybe some SUSHI? SABRA hummus? Or a taco with BARBACOA and SALSA? Well...maybe some SOUL food. Okay, then, PASTA it is!]
Feels like the difficulty levels have been all over the map lately. This felt like an easy Monday.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/10/20/tuesday-october-21-2025/#ny David Connell, if you're out there, thank you for teaching me the etymology of GAMUT.

The games app has been giving me issues all day. It had me log back in first thing this morning, then didn‚Äôt recognize that I had finished any of the games today. After closing and reopening several times, it finally updated all of my stats, but my comment on the Tuesday puzzle that I posted at 7:20 pm Pacific time still has yet to show up. üòí 
#annoyedonthewestcoast
I must confess I have never heard the term BASEMENT PARTY until today.  Is it just a party in someone's basement, or is there more to it than that?

A lackadaisical kind of puzzle, with a lot of self-fillers spiced up with some HARDASSED clues, just to keep us AMUSEd.  Fun to work, and, as I'm sure many others have said, NICELYDONE!

Thank you, Spencer.
Nice puzzle except for the BARBACOA/HANES cross which (as a Brit) I regard as an unfair confluence of Naticks, although I‚Äôm sure y‚Äôall gonna tell me these are well known States-side‚Ä¶
Fun and easy. Some different clues and answers than the usual but not arcane.

Well I‚Äôll say this it made me look up Questlove. One clue I might have just ignored, but two I gotta find out who the dude is.
Clever theme and well constructed

.

Are there really folks out there whose partners give them a TREAT when they agree to roll over to hog less of the bed? Just to think that I‚Äôve cooperated all these years for nary a Smartie. Well, there‚Äôs one born every minute, right?

Ah, TRUST-building exercises. The ones I‚Äôve lived through haven‚Äôt been too bad. The worst that‚Äôs done to a bunch of pasty academics is usually a pub quiz. A little blood gets drawn, sure‚Äîthat‚Äôll happen with a bunch of Type A‚Äôs vying for a prize‚Äîbut (almost) everyone survives. My husband‚Äôs company, on the other hands, once whisked him off half way across the country to some muddy place in Oklahoma with an actual drill sergeant. The mud was real. They crawled through it. He came home in one piece courtesy of lots of ibuprofen and a genetic makeup not given to PTSD. Many fared worse.  

For some reason I keep DOOKing 41A as a nonsensical Spanish phrase (or possibly a plug for a mattress company): LA SERTA GARENA. That‚Äôs my cue to say thank you to Spencer Leach for a great start to my day and pour another cuppa. 

Have a good day, everyone.

IS IT just me, or are constructors (overly) celebrating their ability to include [ahem] ‚Äúrear end‚Äù [ahem]?  It uses common letters and can be clued in so many amusing ways!

Nice puzzle. Easier than yesterday‚Äôs IMHO. 
YMMV.

The SE (or lower right, @B) corner was impossibly hard for me. I've never heard of HANES. I pride myself of knowing nothing about the family whose name I will not mention. I eat sushi but I don't understand what most of its names mean. I'm not familiar with American-Mexican cuisine beyond a few basics. I have no idea why "Cone or sphere" solves to SOLID (is it a geometry thing? If so, our terminology is different. Not that I remembered it after 30 years, but I looked up what I think was meant there, and it's called "figura przestrzenna", literally "[three]dimensional shape") I had to resort to lookups in that area. So much factual knowledge crammed into a small space hardly felt fair ü•≤ In the SW or lower left corner I was faced with STEALSHO_E. You'd think that one missing letter would be a gimme, wouldn't you? I went for P ü§£. The cross was little help, as it was 50% empty - its first letter was part of the name of an American hummus brand... Also, before I got more crosses I only entered N__B for the beginner gamer. You can never know if it's going to be spelled NOOB or NewB. This was not my day ü§∑üèΩ Every day is Lucek's day though. Here he is looking out on the terrace yesterday: https://imgur.com/a/KOUxaMg
I have to admit I was confused by SOLID. From the article I gather it's a geometric designation, but can't you have hollow cones and spheres?

My second personal best in a bow!

As a South African, I struggled a bit in the SE corner because of BARBACOA and HANES; plus I would never have gotten SOLID without the crossings.

Now that I know what BARBACOA is, I enjoyed its crossing with SALSA:) 

I don‚Äôt know if ACES is a hand? I started with PAIR as it strikes me as the only hand that fits (in the glove, haha). 

I didn‚Äôt know ACORN was a hue given how much the colour can vary with species and ripeness. Seems like a not great basis for a hue‚Ä¶

GAMUT was my favourite entry because this beautiful word is underused in everyday language. 

PS this puzzle made hungry! (SOUP, SUSHI, SALSA, ALE, BOWL, TREAT).
I thought that the Monday and Tuesday puzzles could have been switched, and many of the comments indicated similar thoughts.  Not a complaint however, as I enjoyed the solve.

Because of the internet issues associated with AWS yesterday I sent this to the email provided,

"All of my streaks were set back to zero after yesterday's internet difficulties.   Strands, spelling bee, wordle and connections were all affected.   I was at 86 perfect Strands completion and today back to zero.

While in the grand scheme of things these "streaks" mean pretty much nothing, but I would say they offer different levels of motivation to many people based on their circumstances."

I received an unhelpful automated reply.   

To quote Pink Floyd, "Welcome to Machine"
My hometown, a lovely puzzle, and a Tuesday PB all in one day? What a treat!

Sorry to cross-pollinate, but has anyone been able to access the Spelling Bee comments today?

I can open the forum homepage but can't see the little speech bubble icon for the comments. 

Also some of the comments sections for the other games seem to be closed.  Is it just me?  This is the first place I've been able to post!
Ah, so I see in the grid, sometimes the ACORN does fall far from the TREE.
I was close to finishing at around 12 minutes, took a break to make some coffee and when I came back my time was back at 00:00. It was a quick solve, but not under three minutes!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Original theme, never done before.  Although I like the clue once given to SHOT IN THE DARK:  ["____?  It‚Äôd be better to administer a vaccine with the lights on‚Äù].
‚Ä¢	NDA made me think of its anagram AND, which made me think of yesterday‚Äôs AD-FREE puzzle.
‚Ä¢	Fun semordnilap fact: NORI is rich in iron.
‚Ä¢	All four theme entries are NYT answer debuts, giving this theme pop.
‚Ä¢	Fun to see AGE / ATE / ADE / ALE in the box.
‚Ä¢	Do crossing answers ACES and MESAS rhyme? Discuss.
‚Ä¢	A low word count for Tuesday at 72, more typical for Friday.  It allows for more longs than usual on this day, lovely downs like NICELY DONE, STEALS HOME, and BARBACOA.

Pop, originality, loveliness and more radiating from your puzzle, Spencer, making for a splendid outing.  Thank you!
Nice and easy. My best Tuesday time. I‚Äôve never been to a BASEMENT PARTY, maybe that‚Äôs why I didn‚Äôt understand how it connects to the theme.

I like how SALSA mirrors the theme,
since it is as hot in the dark as it is in the full glare of star light,
according to astronomers‚Äô best guesses, anyway.

Nice solid puzzle, which, for me, was easier than yesterday's. Might have chosen to run this one on a Monday. In any case, I enjoyed the puzzle. My only goof was NEWB instead of NOOB, which the crosses quickly fixed.

I was idly wondering what the theme was, how all these weird long themers connected, so had a laugh at the revealer.

And noticed the mini-themes of Japanese food, and Mexican food, and Questlove soul food.
And soup and hummus and pasta and other TREATs.

Was Spencer Leach hungry or planning a party?
Tied my Speediest Tuesday Ever Recorded.
Five minutes! That's a record Tuesday for me!

Got stuck on 52 down, and missed out on a PB by 54 seconds. But, you know, I'm really OK with that... I'd rather have worked my way around the word, or (in the end, I'll happily admit) consult the oracle, than to have actually known the answer off the top of my head!!
I‚Äôm so old, I remember when you could leave your Lego unlocked.

What do you have when a great white gets the measles?  

A DOT IN THE SHARK.
I had Shape before SOLID and Stab before SHOT IN THE DARK. Other than that, a quick solve. No ear worms from me today. NICELY DONE, Spencer.

I thought for a while I‚Äôd have a personal best but hit a couple snags in the south and fell short. Still, the easy solve helped salve a bit the technical frustration of yesterday. I‚Äôd never heard of BARBACOA, was certain 59A was ‚Äúshape‚Äù instead of SOLID, and the names of the K-family that consumes so much social oxygen don‚Äôt come automatically to me. I am not complaining about their inclusion in a XW since my knowledge and preferences shouldn‚Äôt describe the universe of NYT crosswords‚Ä¶just summing up the snag I hit.

In all, I found it a pleasant experience, sitting on my deck on this chilly morning, looking out over the woods behind my house, having coffee, listening to Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers, and tackling the crossword as I attempt to stifle my urge to look at the news and, instead, try to focus on pockets of the sane and the good.

I'm back. Anyway, a typical slow Tuesday for me, but an enjoyable solve. And... my puzzle find today (Hi Lewis): A Sunday from April 6, 1969 by Nancy Schuster with the title: "The gang's all here." Some answers in that one: BOSTONTEAPARTY GRANDOLDPARTY PARTYPOLITICS TWOPARTYSYSTEM BEAPARTYTO SEARCHPARTY PARTYPOOPER PARTYLINES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/6/1969&g=23&d=A ....

Thank you, Spencer, for a nice smooth grid today!  I also achieved my best Tuesday solving time today so, of course, such a TREAT makes me take a shine to the constructor whenever I feel I have ACEd it.‚òÄÔ∏è 

Happy Tuesday, everyone!

Ripped through this one quickly... not personal best quickly though (my best was 14 seconds faster). However I only have XWSTATS synced back a little more than a year, and it is indeed my fastest Tuesday during that period. For those saying it felt more like a Monday puzzle, in my case it was still a minute slower than my Monday best, but indeed faster than my average time for a Monday. 

I think one reason BARBACOA was a tough one for many is that you don't see it in old-school Tex-Mex-style restaurants, but it's very common at taco stands/trucks. I've only begun frequenting places like that in the last few years, so it seems "new" to me.

Yesterday I discovered the monthly bonus puzzle.  How did I not know about this and why can we not comment on those puzzles and the wonderful themes they provide?  OMG.  Am I the only one to have recently found this!!?!

Gee, I haven't watched A SHOT IN THE DARK in a very long time. I wonder how it holds up? And just imagine what Blake Edwards and Peter Sellers could have done with this jewel heist at the Louvre. Seriously, the thieves dropped Empress Eugenie's crown on the way out, and escaped on scooters. The script practically writes itself.
Am I the only one to think that the shot taken in the dark basement might be romantic rather than alcoholic?
Blazed through this one for new Tuesday best of 3:21!

Two things: 

1) Mr Leach seems to like his SUSHI. I count 3 sushi related clues. Perhaps today's image should've been of SUSHI?

2) I can't believe I didn't get BARBACOA on the first try. And the best BARBACOA? South Philly Barbacoa of course! You can check out the chef Cristina Martinez's story on Chef's Table, or better yet, get down there to try it if you haven't already.

I'm back and what a purely blissful cruise vacation it was!!! Ahhhh!!! Or is it Aaaaah? Never do know that one in the crosswords.

I was quite unplugged‚ÄîI even turned off all my work notifications, etc. which I'm not always good at. It's so good to now work where they expect me to really vacate on my vacation. I didn't have that for a long time and appreciate it so much now, even after five years here. It's hard to erase the previous two decades but I'm immensely grateful for now. As usual, I digress.  I did the puzzles every day, usually while sweet husband dozed in the sun and I lounged beside him. I don't care about streaks, so I didn't feel a pressure, it was just fun. 

I enjoyed today's offering! It was surprisingly a personal best. Wonder how good it could have been if I hadn't stopped to sip my Diet Coke or scratch my nose... 

Today, I didn't follow my usual across then down pattern, I was on a roll and just did sections at a time, with only a slowdown or two, like NOOB-v-NewB, thinking of carnitas before BARBACOA (easily resolved, though I have a slight taste preference for the former) and PASTASHEet before SHELL. I thought PASTASHEet was not a good answer but one does sometimes roll them with goodness inside, so maybe?  I was glad I had to change it though. 

Wow, pasta, tacos, and sushi these are a few of my favorite TREATS...  Mmm! Must be lunchtime... Where's the buffet in this lousy place!? Sheesh!  Zero stars!!!  Har!

Such a fun puzzle! Thanks Spencer Leach üëèüèª

What‚Äôs wrong with me? I‚Äôve been eating tacos and Mexican food all my life -it‚Äôs my favorite- how is the word Barbacoa absolutely unknown to me? Had to google it! I don‚Äôt recall seeing it on any menu, nuthin‚Äô!
Bravo!

For some reason my mind went to Hines, the ketchup instead of the underwear, and birria as the food.   My mind eventually righteditself and came up with Hanes and barbacoa (both of which are not totally uncommon out here).   Michael Jordan used to be the face of Hanes for decades.

Loved this Tuesday. And TIL ‚ÄúBarbacoa‚Äù
Have a good day y‚Äôall!

Super cute theme, I liked this puzzle a lot! As a 6D, I feel compelled to share a bit of trivia that I make sure to instill in my students: just because we're used to 19As taking thermal images, 39A brighter=hotter, we shouldn't get used to associating infrared light with the quality of heat. In fact, infrared radiation is less energetic and cooler than the light we can see with our eyes!
I found 28D to be quite PAST AS HELL. It's really throwing me back.
This was WAY too easy, felt like a beginner Monday!

Lots of fun, just the right difficulty for a Tuesday, and a great theme!

I'm embarrassed to admit that I only learned about BARBACOA the first time I ate at Chipotle many years ago.

Wow! Infrared cameras, basement dance parties, and laser tag arenas: I want to hang out with Spencer Leach! A note on GAMUT: a while back, I posted a comment on the medieval origins of the names for the notes of the scale--how, before it was Do-Re-Mi, it was Ut-Re-Mi. Actually, medieval music theorists had a system of interlocking, six-note scales (hexachords)--so any given pitch was fully designated by both its letter name (A-G) and its position on the scale: so, B-Mi, or E-La. Also, since the only music worth considering was the liturgical chant being sung by monks, the full compass of notes was that which a (male) human voice can produce (falsetti and boys included): in other words, from the bottom of the (modern) bass clef to the E an octave and a third above middle C. Oh, and there weren't any sharps or flats, except for B-flat. Go figure. Anyway, you would think that the first, lowest note in this system would be (low) "A," but no--the bottom note ("Ut"), on the bottom hexachord, was designated by the Greek letter Gamma--thus "Gamma-ut"--hence "Gamut," hence the term for the system as a whole. Here's a couple of underground dance parties: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oou2ywIbRxc&list=RDoou2ywIbRxc&start_radio=1 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=grtFa34EdgI (I know which one I'd rather crash.)

Spanners and a theme that made sense, and cute parallel clues (such as Questlove's hair and project) throughout‚Äîwhat's not to like? Maybe a little easy, since I PR'd (and came in a few seconds under yesterday), but I'm not complaining.
Brilliantly done!
A sphere is not a solid. A sphere is a surface, and the solid it encloses is called a ball.

Editors: 

Can we please settle on a clue for 22A that doesn't make us Lego fans grind our teeth?

I got hung up on ASTRONOMER because I‚Äôve never heard that world until today. I had ASTROLOGER because that is the only science that accurately describes the heavens. 

Interestingly, the first time Galileo observed Sagittarius he is reported to have yelled in a high squeaky voice, ‚ÄúOooh!  Ooooooh!  Yummykins!!‚Äù
What a fun puzzle, Mr. Leach!  Loved the Lego, Minecraft, food, and Questlove clues today.  Thanks for the enjoyable challenge.  Let's see what tomorrow brings!

Surprised not to see people talking about 28D more. My wife and I have a long-standing debate over the difference between pasta and noodles. I consider a single pasta shell to be pasta but not a noodle; she considers it a noodle but not pasta.

üëçüèΩüëçüèΩüëçüèΩ!!!

@SBK
Thanks, all, for letting me share my joy. It was, as usual with the Cardiac Jays, a come-from-behind victory.

The moment came in the 7th inning when George Springer -- you remember him, he took a fastball off the kneecap in the previous game and had to be helped off the field because he couldn't walk -- he stepped up to bat and astoundingly hit a three-run home run. In his mid-30s, ancient in baseball years, after a miserable 2024 season, hearing talk that his remaining contract was now a write-off, George woke up in 2025, seemed to shake off Father Time's grimy paws, and had the best season of  his career.

Well, enough. I could write 20 such stories but this isn't the sport pages. My compliments to the Mariners, my sympathies to their fans. We're off to the World Series.

I am crazy happy.

@SBK
Congratulations to you, even though my husband is nearly in tears. It‚Äôs the first thing he checked when he woke up this morning. Flags must be at half mast back home. 

Just read your post about your experience with refugee interviews, btw. Your impression of Chinese‚Äîor any East Asian language‚Äîprosody mirrors mine. 

(A wistful) good luck to the Jays!

@Sam Lyons

I will say that, while I was pulling for Toronto, I think I know what Seattle fans are feeling.  And I wish that wasn't the other side of the coin.

"We came so close.  It happens so infrequently to get this close, and now it's gone.  Now we start all over.  What are the chances the team is this good next year?  How long do we have to wait?"

I don't know what fraction of the baseball fan population has to deal with this, but it's nearly every team other than a five or six that regularly have competitive seasons.

The New York/Los Angeles markets** get a team at least a time or two in a generation.  And they've both had bona fide dynasties.   But there are so many teams with so many fewer fans, and so much less ability to sign free agents.

I was once a Pirates fan.  I have not heard a word about them for decades.

**I realize that the Chicago teams, also a big market, are also uncannily hapless.  

Now I'll go yell at clouds or grass or something.

@Sam Lyons
Thanks for this generous note, Sam. And by way of comforting your husband, you might remind him of what Seattle did to us a few years ago in what was then the 3-game wild card series. (We led the M's by 7 runs and they dug themselves out of the trough, took the game and the series!) That was our turn under the plough. Perhaps we'll see each other again in next year's  AL Championship.

@SBK 

Fantastic! Congratulations to you and all your fellow Canadians. I‚Äôm glad to see a team from north of the border get into the World Series. Go Jays!

@Francis
What did the clouds or grass ever do to you?
You poignantly ask on behalf of smaller market teams: "What are the chances the team is this good next year?  How long do we have to wait?"
We're asking that too, even in the midst of our joy. So much of our success was lightning in a bottle -- players suddenly finding their hitting form or rookies succeeding because there was no 'form' on their tendencies, so their pitches were unpredictable. 

So many of our players only got their moment because someone with a bigger rep or better numbers was injured and there was a gap to be filled. No injury, no gap, and that second-rank player would have languished in Buffalo. Some of this year's "stars" were throw-ins on deals we made for bigger names. 

Luck counts for so much, even for a player with good natural skills who applies himself. And the players know it.  Ernie Clement was a journeyman player six months ago. Now he's among the top 10 hitters for average and is nominated for two Golden Gloves. Where did this come from? He cheerfully admits that he has no idea. He makes a pro forma acknowledgement  of the coaching the Jays gave him, but ask the coaches? They'll say that they're groping in the dark half the time too.

@Elizabeth Connors

In that case, you should be disappointed that Seattle didn't win; they are the only team never to reach the World Series

@SBK

Yeah, I was waiting for a response to maybe make my point a little clearer.  

It's not that small market teams never win the World Series.  They do fairly frequently.  But unless they are one of a few big payroll teams, chances are quite high that their reliably talented players will evaporate to bigger spending teams in the coming years.  Then they'll go back into a hibernation of god-knows-how long.

Until lightning strikes again.

@Sam Lyons
I have to laugh. My real sports are curling -- the only Olympic sport I ever played -- and baseball. During their championship seasons, I /may/ look at hockey or even basketball. But I never give a moment to football. It's complicated, poorly structured, alienating (who can even see the players' faces?), slow-footed, violent...well, suffice it to say I don't care who wins whatever bowl is being contested next week. I think that pigskin is just a misuse of perfectly good cracklings.

@SBK

Congratulations!

George Springer channeling Kirk Gibson, a Dodger!

I appreciate that many, if not most, people want life/work balance. Until recently, most Americans didn‚Äôt *expect* it‚Äînot unless they didn‚Äôt care about making money‚Äîbut that‚Äôs changing, partly because of ideas coming over from Europe. Having said that, there are professions in which life vs. work is a distinction without a difference. 

My work is my passion is my life, as it is for my friends and colleagues‚Äîas well as my Gen Z graduate students, despite the news media‚Äôs touting them as the life/work-balance generation. I‚Äôm surprised to read your post, in fact, because I don‚Äôt often meet people in academia who talk about ‚Äúhours outside of work.‚Äù Presumably one goes into higher education because it is his or her life‚Äôs work. 

I‚Äôm here on a very generous grant to research, write, and teach. Just like my entire adult life, if I‚Äôm not ‚Äúactively‚Äù working, I‚Äôm talking or thinking about work. Is thinking at dinner about my mentee‚Äôs dissertation work? Is discussing it with a colleague during a morning run? Is it work or life when I‚Äôm rubbing my cat‚Äôs chin with one hand while scrolling through a journal article with the other? What is it at 1am in a pub after a conference (and a lot of beer) arguing about Hittite grammar? 

My husband‚Äôs ‚Äúbasic training‚Äù experience was a retreat during which the executive cadre rethought the company‚Äôs future. Believe me, they all went there with bells on. No longer being able to do these things is to him the greatest tragedy of his illness.

@The X-Phile

It‚Äôs not called begging; it‚Äôs called negotiating.

@Sam Lyons

I think about my work all the time, in a way. In order to be able to teach about law and public administration, I have to know about both, not only on a theoretical level but also on a practical one. Thus, for example, when out on a walk with my dog, I analyze my surroundings to determine to what extent law is being implemented, and if the ideals of modern public management have any bearing on how the public administration attempts to satisfy people's collective needs. I find those things quite interesting, too.

Yet I actually abandoned a scholarly career in favor of a laid-back teaching track because I had no passion for hardcore research and its formal and financial requirements. The work/life balance for a scholar skews too much towards work, IMO.

My ruminations on walks notwithstanding, I try to limit to an absolute minimum the hours I spend on work-related activities in the narrow sense. I do my job well - I am among the best liked teachers at the faculty. I keep improving my teaching materials, I listen to feedback, I take courses to improve my teaching methods and my communication with my students. But I also never check my work email outside typical working hours, I don't spend a minute longer at the faculty building than I need to, I don't seek to personally get to know my students or co-workers, I don't volunteer for anything, I ignore almost all activities that do not fall under the terms of my employment (e.g., team-building events), etc.

@Teresa

I think,  (doing my best not to paraphrase wikipedia), 

I think it has more to do with formal geometry definitions.  There are some basic solids (there's no concept of hollow or full in these definitions).

They have the property of being in three dimensions.

@Teresa Geometrically speaking, a SOLID is any shape having three dimensions. A plane has two, and a point has one. Just thinking about a cone for a moment, the solid shape would be defined by a circle at the base, and the sides connecting the circle to another point, the point of the cone.

If it were what we think of as a hollow cone in real life, that shape is actually defined by a circular ring and two shapes connecting the ring to the point of the cone: the inside of the cone and the outside of the cone. It's easier to think of these if the hollow cone is thick on the sides, then you can see the circular ring at the base and feel that the inside is smaller than the outside. But it's also the case for a cone made of paper, because the paper has thickness, albeit small to us.

@Teresa

Both "cone" and "sphere" have a variety of meanings, both within mathematics and in wider usage. For example, the locus of points (x,y,z) in space for which x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 1 is the (unit) sphere. It is a *surface*, not a solid. If it were filled, I as a mathematician would call it the (unit) "ball". Similarly, the locus of points for which x^2 + y^2 - z^2 = 0 would be a mathematical cone---sometimes referred to as a "double cone" since it consists of two nappes. Again, this is a surface, and not a solid. If the "=" in the equation were replaced with a "‚â§", then we'd have what I would call a "solid cone".

For those who still need convincing, from wikipedia:
Mathematicians consider a sphere to be a two-dimensional closed surface embedded in three-dimensional Euclidean space. They draw a distinction between a sphere and a ball, which is a solid figure, a three-dimensional manifold with boundary that includes the volume contained by the sphere."

That's a pretty picky distinction, not made in everyday use; but then, the clue was, specifically, for the geometrical term SOLID, so we should defer to the mathematicians.

@Bill

Agreed, if you want to clue something geometrically then I guess you gotta play by the rules.
In math class, a sphere is not a solid; in English class it can be. The clue doesn't say we're studying geometry. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sphere

@Barry Ancona

So when I commented to Bill I thought the clue specifically said in geometry; but it didn‚Äôt, it just said cone or sphere, which in everyday English use certainly are solids and your point is well taken. 
Still it‚Äôs interesting to note that officially the points on the sphere do not include the inside (although it is still called solid geometry). Also interesting you can calculate the ‚Äúvolume‚Äù of a sphere but maybe should say ‚Äúvolume enclosed by a sphere‚Äù.
Finally it‚Äôs interesting that mathematicians have a separate word for ‚Äúball‚Äù and ‚Äúsphere‚Äù but what do they do about cone? Or dodecahedron for that matter? Do they go around saying ‚Äúthe solid object whose surface is described by a dodecahedron‚Äù?
